Award.AwardTitle: FIRSTIV:Faculty Institutes for Reforming Science Teaching for Postdoctoral Research Scholars

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This multi-institution professional development project for postdoctoral scholars is shaping their beliefs about and approaches to teaching undergraduate biology, to ultimately result in improved student learning. The project focuses on creating a national network of 200 postdoctoral scholars who are prepared and mentored in scientific teaching before they assume faculty roles in academic institutions. The professional development activities explicitly link the principles of scientific research with those of scientific teaching. Established Regional Field Station (RFS) leadership teams are implementing professional development workshops, providing mentoring in teaching and long-term support for postdoctoral scholars, and advancing their own teaching and scholarship in education. The postdoctoral scholars are learning teaching strategies and constructing an entire biology course based on scientific teaching. They are adapting pre-existing materials and tools that are learner-centered, and tested and validated by other faculty. It is anticipated that the postdoctoral scholars will begin their new faculty positions formally prepared to teach with a course in hand. The project is evaluating the effect of professional development on postdoctoral understanding and implementation of the scientific approach to teaching and active student-centered learning. The new courses are being disseminated through the FIRST web site and the FIRST Assessment Database, which is linked to websites of the National Postdoctoral Association, the National STEM Digital Library and scientific societies. The effectiveness of these professional development and teaching reform models is being disseminated through publications and presentations based on analyses of the postdoctoral scholars in their original and new institutional positions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Faculty Institutes for Reforming Science Teaching (FIRST IV) is a professional development program through which we trained 201 postdoctoral fellows in biology who currently teach or will teach teach undergraduate students at colleges and universities throughout the US. The participants in FIRST IV were trained in state-of-the-art teaching using the principles of teaching science based on evidence of effective practices. Participants were taught how and why to create classrooms in which students are active learners and critical thinkers (i.e., learner-centered classrooms), and how to develop transformed courses that enable all students to learn science. We have exciting new evidence showing that focusing professional development activities on early-career teaching practitioners is effective in the short-term and provides a structural model to inform the design of future professional development activities. The results from the FIRST IV project confirmed that the design and methods of implementation that we used were uniquely successful in producing learner-centered faculty. We do not know of any other training program for college and university faculty that is as effective as FIRST IV. The findings from our project will influence subsequent professional development programs that aim to transform undergraduate Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education.

The first unique component of FIRST IV was the focus on postdoctoral (postdoc) scholars, who will become early career faculty, rather than on faculty who were already experienced in teaching. The second key component was that the postdocs reviewed and critically evaluated their understanding of transformed teaching along with practicing their teaching during a two-year period. During those two years the postdocs underwent a repeated process of learning new teaching strategies during workshops, implementing them in their actual teaching, and critically reviewing videos of their teaching with mentors and peers. The FIRST IV professional development model has key elements that are adaptable to various types of programs and institutions. Unlike most previous reports about professional development, our results are based on rigorous, repeatable, and objective evaluation, thereby enhancing its potential use by STEM educators.

The FIRST IV professional development model was aimed at answering, in part, the nationwide call to action for changing biology instruction. During implementation of the FIRST IV program, the participants contributed to improving teaching and learning of biology in approximately 400 courses (~10,000 students) in 220 biology departments nationwide at which FIRST IV team leaders and postdocs taught. Our evaluation results demonstrated that postdocs exiting the FIRST IV program believed in and implemented learner-centered teaching. Furthermore, their teaching practice significantly differed from that of comparison faculty at the start of their first faculty position. Thus, FIRST IV faculty may serve as agents of change in teaching in their departments.
